title: Cite - GEM-pRF | Citation Information
text: Cite - GEM-pRF | Citation Information GEM-pRF Cite Here's the link to our research paper published in Medical Image Analysis: Mittal et al. (2025), GEM-pRF: GPU-Empowered Mapping of Population Receptive Fields for Large-Scale fMRI Analysis

title: Configuration - GEM-pRF | XML Configuration Guide
text: Configuration - GEM-pRF | XML Configuration Guide GEM-pRF Configuration Quick Overview ‚öôÔ∏è GEM-pRF uses a simple XML configuration file. üìÑ All analysis settings, paths, and parameters live inside this file. üöÄ Your Python code stays tiny, you only call gp.run(CONFIG_FILEPATH) . üîÅ Create multiple XML files to run multiple analyses easily. üìÇ GEM-pRF stores a copy of your XML file inside the analysis output folder. ‚ö° Use Configuration Generator to create XML files through an interactive web interface. üíæ Download a sample config file to get started quickly. The configuration file is the heart of GEM-pRF . If the XML file is correct, GEM-pRF will run smoothly - no code changes needed. Why an XML configuration file? GEM-pRF keeps analysis settings separate from the code. Instead of editing Python scripts, you adjust the XML ‚Äî flexible,simple, safe, and easy to automate. No code editing: all parameters are defined in the XML. Batch processing: create multiple config files and run them in sequence. Automation: call gp.run() in a loop or run a bash script over a folder of XML files. Reproducibility: GEM-pRF automatically saves the XML file inside the analysis output directory. Clarity: well-named XML files make it easy to track analyses. Recommended naming conventions While not required, giving your XML files meaningful names makes your work much easier to understand later. A BIDS-style naming convention works very well. study-CHN_task-fixedbar123_run-concat_analysis-02_desc-hres.xml Clear naming helps you recognize what the analysis did even years later. How to run GEM-pRF using a config file Once gemprf and the matching CuPy build are installed, run GEM-pRF using: import gemprf as gp gp.run("path/to/your_config.xml") GEM-pRF reads everything from the XML file ‚Äî data paths, stimuli, parameters, output locations ‚Äî and executes the full analysis automatically. Where to edit the XML file Use an editor that highlights XML tags clearly, so you can avoid small mistakes and see the structure of the configuration file at a glance. VS Code (recommended, easy to use and has great XML highlighting) Notepad++ (lightweight and works well on Windows systems) Sublime Text, Atom, or any editor that provides XML syntax coloring and indentation support See a full configuration example A complete example configuration file is available on GitHub: Use this example as a template and adjust paths and parameters for your study. For an easier approach, check out the interactive configuration generator in the section below to build your own custom config file step-by-step. Configuration Tools & Resources üõ†Ô∏è Interactive Configuration Generator Need help creating a configuration file? Use our interactive generator to build your XML configuration step-by-step: ‚öôÔ∏è Open Configuration Generator üì• Download Sample Configuration Get started quickly by downloading our sample configuration file. You can use it as a starting point for your own analyses. ‚¨á Download Sample Configuration üìö Configuration Archives Looking for configuration files for older GEM-pRF versions? Browse our archive of configurations: üì¶ View Config Archive

title: Download GEM-pRF | GPU-Accelerated fMRI Tool
text: Download GEM-pRF | GPU-Accelerated fMRI Tool GEM-pRF Download GEM-pRF GEM-pRF can be downloaded in two ways, depending on your access and workflow. 1. Download from PyPI (recommended) The easiest and most common way to install GEM-pRF is directly from PyPI: pip install gemprf The latest release is available here: PyPI ‚Äì gemprf . After installation, see Running for instructions on running GEM-pRF. 2. Source Code This option is useful for contributors or advanced users who want to inspect the implementation, debug, or modify the code. For most users, installing from PyPI is the recommended and simplest method. 3. Sample Configuration File Once you have GEM-pRF installed, you'll need a configuration file to run your analysis. A sample configuration file is provided below to give you a sense of how GEM-pRF configurations work. Don't worry if it looks intimidating at first! XML configuration files are actually quite straightforward once you understand the basic structure. Most settings are well-commented, and you only need to modify a few key parameters for your analysis. If you have any questions or run into difficulties, don't hesitate to reach out to the GEM-pRF authors . We're here to help! ‚¨á Download Sample Configuration

title: GEM-pRF - Population Receptive Field Mapping | pRF Software for Retinotopy
text: GEM-pRF - Population Receptive Field Mapping | pRF Software for Retinotopy GEM-pRF GPU-Empowered Mapping Highly Accurate Retinotopic Maps Quickstart Welcome to GEM-pRF - a standalone, plug-and-play software for population receptive field (pRF) mapping, designed for large-scale data analysis with high accuracy. To understand the theoretical foundations and details of how the software works, please refer to our paper: Mittal et al. (2025), GEM-pRF: GPU-Empowered Mapping of Population Receptive Fields for Large-Scale fMRI Analysis Follow these steps to quickly get up and running with GEM-pRF : Begin with the Installation Guide to set up your environment. Proceed to Running GEM-pRF for instructions on executing the software.

title: Installation - GEM-pRF | GPU-Accelerated fMRI Analysis
text: Installation - GEM-pRF | GPU-Accelerated fMRI Analysis GEM-pRF Installation Quick Overview ‚úÖ Check your system has an NVIDIA GPU ‚ö° Install CUDA SDK üì¶ Install CuPy (matching your CUDA version) ‚¨áÔ∏è Install GEM-pRF using pip Step-by-Step Guide GEM-pRF requires an NVIDIA GPU and CUDA for accelerated pRF computation. Make sure your system has a compatible GPU available. ‚ö†Ô∏è Ensure your system has a compatible NVIDIA GPU available. Step 1. Create a new python environment (recommended) Create a fresh conda environment: conda create --name gemprf python=3.10 conda activate gemprf Step 2. Set up GPU environment Install the CUDA SDK . Check your CUDA installation: nvcc --version nvidia-smi Install a CuPy build that matches your CUDA version: pip install cupy-cuda12x # Replace 12x with your CUDA version Step 3. Verify CUDA‚ÄìCuPy compatibility Run a quick test to confirm CuPy can use the CUDA runtime correctly: python -c "import cupy as cp; print(cp.arange(5) ** 2)" If this fails, your CuPy build does not match your CUDA runtime. Step 4. Install GEM-pRF via pip Install from PyPI: pip install gemprf Latest releases: PyPI ‚Äì gemprf Step 5. Try the GEMpRF-DemoKit (optional) Follow the instructions in the Getting Started with GEMpRF-DemoKit tutorial to verify your installation. ‚úÖ Once installed, proceed to Running GEM-pRF .

title: Privacy Policy - GEM-pRF | Data Protection & GDPR Compliance
text: Privacy Policy - GEM-pRF | Data Protection & GDPR Compliance GEM-pRF Privacy Policy Last Updated: January 2026 At GEM-pRF, we take your privacy seriously. This policy explains how we collect, use, process, and protect your personal data in accordance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and other applicable data protection laws. Table of Contents 1. Data Controller 2. What Data We Collect 3. How We Use Your Data 4. Legal Basis for Processing 5. Data Retention 6. Who Has Access to Your Data 7. Your Data Rights 8. Third-Party Services 9. Data Security 10. Cookies & Tracking 11. Children's Privacy 12. Contact Us 1. Data Controller The data controller responsible for your personal data is: GEM-pRF Development Team Email: If you have any questions about data protection or wish to exercise your rights, please contact us at the email address above. 2. What Data We Collect We collect personal data only through direct interactions with our website. Specifically: Support Form Data: When you submit the support form, we collect your name, email address, subject, and message. Analytics Data: We use Google Analytics to understand how visitors use our website. This includes anonymized information about pages visited, time spent, and general location (country-level). We do not collect any sensitive data (racial/ethnic origin, religious beliefs, political opinions, biometric data, health data, etc.) unless explicitly and intentionally provided by you in support communications. 3. How We Use Your Data Your personal data is used only for the following purposes: Responding to Support Requests: To understand your inquiry and provide technical assistance, setup help, and feedback resolution. Communication: To send follow-up messages related to your support request. Website Analytics: To improve our website's functionality and user experience. We will not use your data for marketing purposes, sell your data, or share it with unrelated third parties without your explicit consent. 4. Legal Basis for Processing We process your personal data on the following legal bases under GDPR: Explicit Consent: For support form submissions, we process your data based on your explicit consent through the consent checkbox in the form. Legitimate Interest: For website analytics, we use legitimate interest to improve our services while respecting your privacy through anonymization and aggregation. You can withdraw your consent at any time by contacting us, though this will not affect the lawfulness of processing before withdrawal. 5. Data Retention We retain your data only as long as necessary for the purposes outlined above: Support Form Data: Retained for up to 90 days to allow for follow-up communication and issue resolution. After this period, data is permanently deleted unless you request an extension. Analytics Data: Anonymized and aggregated analytics data is retained according to Google Analytics' default retention policy (14 months). You may request earlier deletion of your data at any time by contacting us. 6. Who Has Access to Your Data Access to your personal data is strictly limited to: Authorized Team Members: Only members of the GEM-pRF development and support team who need access to respond to your inquiry. Service Providers: Formspree (form submission processor) and Google Analytics, both of which have data processing agreements in place. Your data is not shared with any other third parties without your explicit consent. 7. Your Data Rights Under GDPR, you have the following rights regarding your personal data: Right to Access: You can request a copy of all personal data we hold about you. Right to Correction: You can request correction of inaccurate or incomplete data. Right to Deletion: You can request deletion of your data (right to be forgotten) unless we have a legal obligation to retain it. Right to Restrict Processing: You can request that we limit how we process your data. Right to Data Portability: You can request your data in a structured, machine-readable format for transfer to another service. Right to Object: You can object to specific processing activities. Right to Withdraw Consent: If processing is based on consent, you can withdraw it at any time. To exercise any of these rights, please contact us at with a clear description of your request. We will respond within 30 days. 8. Third-Party Services Formspree Your support form submissions are processed through Formspree , which acts as a data processor on our behalf. Formspree: Complies with GDPR and data protection regulations Stores submissions securely Does not use your data for marketing purposes Has a Data Processing Agreement in place with GEM-pRF For more information, see Formspree's Privacy Policy . Google Analytics We use Google Analytics to understand how visitors interact with our website. Google Analytics: Collects anonymized information about pages visited and user behavior Uses cookies to track usage (see section 10 below) Does not identify individual users without additional opt-in Complies with GDPR and data protection regulations For more information, see Google's Privacy Policy . 9. Data Security We implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect your personal data from unauthorized access, alteration, disclosure, or destruction: All form submissions are transmitted via HTTPS encryption Data is stored securely through trusted service providers (Formspree) Access to personal data is restricted to authorized personnel only Regular security reviews and updates are conducted However, no method of transmission over the internet or electronic storage is 100% secure. While we strive to protect your data, we cannot guarantee absolute security. 10. Cookies & Tracking Our website uses the following cookies: Google Analytics Cookies: Used to track website usage and improve user experience. These are analytics cookies that collect anonymized data. Most web browsers allow you to control cookies through browser settings. You can: Disable cookies entirely Allow cookies only from specific sites Clear cookies after each browsing session Opt out of Google Analytics tracking by installing the Google Analytics Opt-Out Browser Add-on Disabling cookies may affect the functionality of our website. 11. Children's Privacy GEM-pRF is a scientific software tool intended for researchers and professionals. We do not knowingly collect personal data from children under the age of 16. If we become aware that we have collected data from a child, we will take steps to delete such information promptly. If you believe we have collected data from a child, please contact us immediately. 12. Contact Us If you have questions about this Privacy Policy, wish to exercise your data rights, or want to report a privacy concern, please contact: Data Protection Contact GEM-pRF Development Team Email: We will respond to all data subject requests within 30 days as required by GDPR. Updates to This Privacy Policy We may update this Privacy Policy from time to time to reflect changes in our practices, technology, legal requirements, and other factors. We will notify you of material changes by updating the "Last Updated" date at the top of this page. Your continued use of our website constitutes your acceptance of the updated Privacy Policy.

title: Running GEM-pRF | Execution Guide
text: Running GEM-pRF | Execution Guide GEM-pRF Running GEM-pRF Quick Overview üìÇ Prepare your XML configuration file. üöÄ Run GEM-pRF directly from Python (recommended). üíª Advanced users can also run GEM-pRF from its entry script. ‚ö†Ô∏è Make sure you have installed GEM-pRF via pip install gemprf and a matching CuPy build. Step-by-Step Guide Option A: Run GEM-pRF from Python (recommended) This is the simplest way to use GEM-pRF. No cloning, no manual entry points. Import the package: import gemprf as gp Run GEM-pRF by providing the path to your XML config file ( see a sample config here ): import gemprf as gp gp.run("path/to/your_config.xml") This works in any Python environment: scripts, Jupyter, VS Code, PyCharm ‚Äî everything. Option B: Advanced ‚Äî Run from entry script (GitHub codebase) For users with full access to the GEM-pRF source code (e.g. debugging, modifying kernels), you can execute GEM from its terminal entry point. Activate your environment and navigate to the GEMpRF folder. Run: python run_gem.py PATH_TO_YOUR_XML_CONFIG_FILE Option C: Run from an IDE (source-code users) Open the GEM-pRF code folder in VS Code or PyCharm. Edit run_gem.py to point to your XML config file. Execute the script directly inside the IDE.

title: Support & Contact - GEM-pRF | Help, Setup, Feedback
text: Support & Contact - GEM-pRF | Help, Setup, Feedback GEM-pRF Support Don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out. Whether you have a question, need setup support, or just want to share feedback, we read every note and will get back to you promptly. Name * Email * Subject * Message * I consent to GEM-pRF processing my data to respond to my support request. * Data Processing Notice: Your name, email, subject, and message will be used solely to respond to your support request. Your data is submitted to Formspree and will be retained for up to 90 days unless you request deletion. You have the right to access, correct, or delete your personal data at any time. View our Privacy Policy Send Support Request Before contacting support, please check: The Installation Guide for setup issues The Running GEM-pRF page for execution questions The Configuration page for config-related issues Our Tutorials for usage examples √ó Privacy & Data Protection Data Controller: GEM-pRF Development Team (contact: ) What data we collect: Your name, email address, subject, and message from the support form. Why we collect it: To understand your inquiry and provide technical support and assistance. Legal basis: Your explicit consent as provided through the form's consent checkbox. Data retention: Your data is retained for up to 90 days to allow time for follow-up communication. You may request deletion of your data at any time. Who has access: Only authorized members of the GEM-pRF support team access your data. Your rights: You have the right to access, correct, delete, or port your personal data. To exercise these rights, please email us directly. Third-party services: Your form data is processed through Formspree , which adheres to GDPR standards. By submitting this form, you consent to this transfer. For our complete Privacy Policy, please visit our full Privacy Policy page .

title: Configuration Files - GEM-pRF | XML Configuration Tutorial
text: Configuration Files - GEM-pRF | XML Configuration Tutorial GEM-pRF Configuration Files GEM-pRF uses XML configuration files to define all analysis inputs and settings. Once gemprf and CuPy are installed, you only need to prepare your XML file and pass its path to the gp.run() function. Running with a Config File import gemprf as gp gp.run("path/to/your_config.xml") A complete example configuration file can be found here: sample_config.xml . You can copy this template, modify paths and parameters, and use it as your starting point for running your own analyses. Helpful Tools & Resources üõ†Ô∏è Interactive Configuration Generator Don't want to manually write XML? Use our interactive configuration generator to build your XML file step-by-step through a user-friendly web interface: Open Configuration Generator ‚Üí üìö Configuration Archives If you're using an older version of GEM-pRF, you can find configuration files for previous releases in our archive: Browse Configuration Archive ‚Üí

title: Grid Fit vs Grid + Refine Fit - GEM-pRF | Fitting Strategy Tutorial
text: Grid Fit vs Grid + Refine Fit - GEM-pRF | Fitting Strategy Tutorial > GEM-pRF Grid Fit vs Grid + Refine Fit One of the key decisions in configuring GEM-pRF is choosing your fitting strategy. GEM-pRF offers two approaches to estimating population receptive fields: grid fitting only or a two-stage approach combining grid fitting with refine fitting . This choice significantly impacts both the speed and accuracy of your analysis. Quick Overview ‚öôÔ∏è Grid Fitting: Fast initial parameter search across a defined space üîß Refine Fitting: Optional fine-tuning for improved accuracy (little slower) üìã Configure via your XML configuration file ‚ö° Choose based on your accuracy vs. speed requirements üéØ Two-stage approach is recommended for most analyses Grid Fitting Grid fitting is the initial stage where GEM-pRF searches across a coarse grid of population receptive field parameters. This stage efficiently explores the parameter space and produces reasonable initial estimates for each voxel. Characteristics of Grid Fitting: Speed: Fast, suitable for large-scale analyses Coverage: Explores the full parameter space systematically Accuracy: Good estimates, but may not capture fine details Use Case: Quick exploratory analyses or when computational resources are limited Refine Fitting Refine fitting (also called fine-fit) is an optional second stage that takes the results from grid fitting and performs a more precise optimization around the best grid solution. This can significantly improve parameter estimates. For detailed information about the gridfit and refinefit algorithms, see the GEM-pRF research paper . Characteristics of Refine Fitting: Speed: Slower than grid fitting alone, but focuses on smaller search space Accuracy: Higher quality parameter estimates with better convergence Optimization: Uses gradient-based methods around the grid solution Use Case: Final, publication-quality analyses Comparing the Two Approaches Aspect Grid Fit Only Grid Fit + Refine Fit Speed Fastest Slower (but still efficient) * Accuracy Good initial estimates Excellent refined estimates * Best For Exploratory analysis, prototyping Publication-quality analysis Parameter Quality Coarse resolution Fine resolution How to Configure Your Fitting Strategy Your choice of fitting strategy is configured through your GEM-pRF XML configuration file. The configuration file controls whether refine fitting is enabled or disabled. XML Configuration Parameters <?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?> <root> <!-- Enable both grid fit and refine fit (recommended) --> <refine_fitting enable="True" refinefit_on_gpu="True"/> <!-- REST OF YOUR CONFIGURATION... --> </root> Parameter Values Description enable True / False Enable or disable refine fitting stage refinefit_on_gpu True / False Run refine fitting on GPU (recommended) or CPU (if memory-limited) Recommendations üí° For Most Users: We recommend using grid fitting combined with refine fitting (the two-stage approach) for your final analyses. The extra computation time is well worth the improvement in parameter quality, and GEM-pRF's GPU acceleration makes this quite fast even for large datasets. ‚ö° For Quick Exploration: If you're testing configurations or doing preliminary analysis, grid fitting alone is sufficient and much faster. You can always switch to the two-stage approach later. Next Steps Try it out: Get started quickly with the GEM-pRF DemoKit , which includes example datasets and configuration files you can experiment with Learn about configuration: Read the Configuration File Tutorial to understand all available options Start with a sample: Use the sample configuration file as a template and modify the fitting strategy to match your needs Monitor performance: Compare the analysis time and result quality between the two approaches to inform your choice for future analyses üìö Learn More: For complete details about configuration options and fitting parameters, see the Configuration File Tutorial .

title: Input Source Selection - GEM-pRF Tutorial | fMRI Data Setup
text: Input Source Selection - GEM-pRF Tutorial | fMRI Data Setup GEM-pRF Tutorial - Input Source Selection Quick Overview üì¶ Make sure GEM-pRF is installed (see the Installation page ) ‚¨áÔ∏è Download the GEMpRF DemoKit ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Run the interactive demo script üîç Choose examples 001‚Äì005 to explore different input source configurations ‚ö†Ô∏è Ensure that you have installed GEM-pRF package (follow the Installation page ). Step-by-Step Guide Step 1. Download the DemoKit This repository contains sample fMRI/MRI data and example configurations. git clone https://github.com/siddmittal/GEMpRF-DemoKit.git cd GEMpRF-DemoKit Step 2. Run the interactive demo The demo script guides you through multiple examples. To explore input sources, select options 001‚Äì005 . python run_gemprf_demo.py Step 3. What happens during the demo Interactive menu : choose examples showing different input styles Automatic path fixing : XML configs update to your local DemoKit paths GPU memory check : prevents running models that won‚Äôt fit Full GEM-pRF run : executes gp.run() using the selected configuration How Input Sources Work GEM-pRF accepts inputs from multiple sources: raw filesystem paths or structured BIDS datasets. Everything is controlled through XML configuration files, not by modifying GEM-pRF code. Filesystem paths : direct references to your fMRI and stimulus files BIDS datasets : GEM-pRF locates the correct files based on subject/session Examples You Will See (001‚Äì005) 001: BIDS + prfprepare (surface), individual runs 002: BIDS + fMRIPrep (surface), individual runs 003: BIDS + fMRIPrep (volume), individual runs 004: BIDS + fMRIPrep (surface + volume), individual runs 005: Fixed paths (non-BIDS) + prfprepare (surface) Notes Ensure GEM-pRF and required dependencies (e.g., CuPy for GPU support) are installed. When adapting examples to your own data, check the XML comments to see which fields control input behaviour.
